issues.text: Whether the appeal was illegally dismissed on the ground of non-compliance with the proviso to Section 9 of the U.P. Sales Tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: That the appeal was illegally dismissed That the assessee-appellant being an importer cannot be considered as one of the successive dealers in the series of sales as contemplated by Section 3A and

issues.text: Whether the assessee, being an importer, can be considered as one of the successive dealers in the series of sales as contemplated by Section 3A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: That the assessee-appellant being an importer cannot be considered as one of the successive dealers in the series of sales as contemplated by Section 3A and That the Notification issued under Section 3A was ultra vires the power granted on the government.

issues.text: Whether the Notification issued under Section 3A of the U.P. Sales Tax Act was ultra vires the power granted to the government?

anchor.surface_text: That the Notification issued under Section 3A was ultra vires the power granted on the government. In order to appreciate the contentions advanced, it is necessary to refer to certain provisions of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the expression 'tax admitted by the appellant to be due' in the proviso to Section 9(1) refers to the admission made before the assessing authority or only in the memorandum of appeal?

anchor.surface_text: What is urged by the learned counsel is that whatever might be the facts admitted in the return and whatever might be the admissions made before the assessing authority it was open to the assessee to take a different stand in its memorandum of appeal and what is relevant for the purpose of Section 9 is the stand taken by the assessee in the memorandum of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In order to appreciate the contentions advanced, it is necessary to refer to certain provisions of the Act. Section 3 1  of the Act provides Subject to the provisions of this Act every dealer shall, for each assessment

arguments.claim: Expression 'tax admitted by the appellant to be due' in proviso to Section 9(1) means admission made before assessing authority, considering returns and Rule 41(2)

anchor.surface_text: Those decisions undoubtedly support the contention of the Appellant but we find it difficult to accept the conclusions reached by the Allahabad High Court and the Kerala High Court. If we come to the conclusion that the expression tax admitted in the proviso to Section 9  1  means that admitted in the memorandum of appeal, section 9 can be made wholly useless.

arguments.claim: Contention that assessee not within Section 3A raised before appellate authority was afterthought and not bona fide

anchor.surface_text: That apart we do not think that the stand taken by the Appellant before the appellate authority can be considered as a bona fide stand. We are of the opinion that the contention taken by the appellant, before the appellate authority that it cannot be brought within the scope of section 3A of the Act was an afterthought.

holdings.text: An importer is one of the successive dealers in the series of sales as contemplated by Section 3A.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, an importer is one of the, dealers. He is the first dealer in the State. The chain of successive dealers begins from the first dealer and it goes upto the last dealer. Any one of the dealers in this chain can be companysidered as a successive dealer. The series do number being in the middle. It must necessarily begin at the very beginning. This is also the view taken by the Allahabad High Court in Ram Kumar Rajendra Swaroop vs. Commissioner of Sales Tax. It is an obvious conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The series of sales by successive dealers commences with the first dealer in the State, being the importer; the series cannot commence from the middle; supported by textual reading and precedent from Allahabad High Court.

holdings.text: The Notification issued under Section 3A is valid and intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: If an importer is one of the successive dealers, which undoubtedly he is, necessarily the notification issued by the Government must be considered to be a valid notification. In this view we reject the last two contentions advanced by Mr. Gupte.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from importer qualifying as successive dealer under Section 3A, empowering government to specify single point including first sale by importer.

holdings.text: The expression 'tax admitted by the appellant to be due' in the proviso to Section 9(1) refers to the tax admitted before the assessing authority, not merely in the memorandum of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Those decisions undoubtedly support the contention of the Appellant but we find it difficult to accept the conclusions reached by the Allahabad High Court and the Kerala High Court. [...] It means that the admission that has got to be taken into consideration is that made before the assessing authority and not before the appellate authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation avoids rendering proviso otiose; harmonious construction with Rule 41(2) requiring payment of instalments due per returns before assessing authority; rejects contrary High Court precedents.

holdings.text: The appeal was properly dismissed for non-compliance with the proviso to Section 9.

anchor.surface_text: Now turning our attention to the first contention advanced by Mr. Gupte, we find there are several difficulties in the way of accepting the same. [...] In this view we reject the last two contentions advanced by Mr. Gupte.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee admitted tax liability of Rs.10,339.19 before assessing authority and collected it but failed to pay/deposit adequately; proviso requires proof of such payment; new stand in appeal irrelevant; contention on S.3A also afterthought.

holdings.text: The assessee's contention before the appellate authority that it was not within Section 3A was an afterthought and not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: That apart we do not think that the stand taken by the Appellant before the appellate authority can be considered as a bona fide stand. We are of the opinion that the contention taken by the appellant, before the appellate authority that it cannot be brought within the scope of section 3A of the Act was an afterthought. No such contention was taken before the assessing authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dispute to S.3A notification before assessing authority despite admissions of liability thereunder.

precedents.citation: Ram Kumar Rajendra Swaroop vs. Commissioner of Sales Tax  1

anchor.surface_text: Ram Kumar Rajendra Swaroop vs. Commissioner of Sales Tax  1 . It is an obvious companyclusion. If an importer is one ,of the successive dealers, which undoubtedly he is, necessarily the numberification issued by the Government must be companysidered to be a valid numberification. In this view we reject the last two companytentions advanced by Mr. Gupte.

In his decision the learned single Judge of the, Kerala High Court has merely followed the Allahabad High Courts decision.

edges.explanation: Rule 12 U.P. Sales Tax Rules, requiring submission of quarterly returns, supports the holding by establishing the formal process for admitting tax before the assessing authority.

Rule 41(2) U.P. Sales Tax Rules, requiring deposit of tax on turnover shown in the return before submission, grounds the holding's interpretation of 'tax admitted' as occurring before the assessing authority, since return submission involves pre-assessment deposit.
The Rule 41(2) requirement for pre-submission deposit addresses the issue of whether 'tax admitted' refers to pre-assessment actions or only later in appeal memorandum.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly, an importer is one of the, dealers. He is the first dealer in the State. The chain of successive dealers begins from the first dealer and it goes upto the last dealer. Any one of the dealers in this chain can be companysidered as a successive dealer. The series do number being in the middle. It must necessarily begin at the very beginning. This is also the view taken by the Allahabad High Court in Ram Kumar Rajendra Swaroop vs. Commissioner of Sales Tax. It is an obvious conclusion.
